review_title: Work-life balance favors life over work.
job_title: Student Services in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The campus is fairly diverse and international, and very liberal; however, administration and staff could be much more diverse. There are many opportunities for smart and serious students to advance themselves and do great things. The alumni network is impressively strong for such a relatively small college. The indulgent environment is well suited for workers who do not like to work very hard.
cons: There is a definite bubble of Mac pride and culture surrounding the campus. If you buy in, you'll love it. If you don't, be prepared to feel like an outsider. Student service staff could be much more professional and student-oriented. Many take advantage of the complete lack of oversight and accountability. The result is that current students aren't getting the services they are entitled to and which they pay a tremendous amount of tuition each year to receive. In my experience, constant "team" formation and mentality means that staff are far less productive, and not at all intent on minimizing the gap between their potential and actual performance. Those with a strong work ethic will be constantly frustrated.

job_title: IT Helpdesk Technician in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Awesome job, I really like it
cons: No cons, I think everything is good as for the student workers

review_title: Excellent place to teach and live
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Smart, engaged, humble students. Very helpful, competent support staff. Friendly, down-to-earth colleagues. Fantastic facilities (library, gym).  Good benefits if you make the right choices and stay long enough to get your money's worth. The Twin Cities is a wonderful place to live: friendly, non-hectic, and affordable -- yet also culturally rich and very cosmopolitan by any (not only Midwestern) standards.
cons: A rabidly liberal ideology permeates all goings-on at the college, from the faculty meetings' agenda to the content of the courses. Many of the students think of themselves as liberal social activists in training, and expect their social lives, extracurriculars, and coursework to be in some way connected with this core mission. Unless you are prepared to actively preach liberal values in the classroom and among other faculty, and to have these values preached back at you by colleagues and students at every turn, you may feel marginalized.  Also: beware the cold Minnesota winters, and the passive-aggressive interaction style known as "Minnesota nice."

review_title: Still great for now, but a changing culture
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Students are wonderful. They come to class prepared to learn and are great about taking what they learn in the classroom and applying it to projects in the real world.
cons: Mac used to have a reputation as a liberal school with a strong social justice bent.  That's changing rapidly under the current admin regime, who wants to remold the school along corporate lines. Many of the current faculty and staff are upset at the changes happening in regards to this. Also that same admin has given themselves obscene pay raises in recent years, while pay for everyone else has stagnated.

job_title: IT Staff in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Very little work.  Summer hours are nice.  Benefits are above average.  Some very nice people to work with and the students are typically friendly and courteous.
cons: If you don't drink the Kool-Aid, you will be miserable.  Some (not all) faculty are beyond arrogant and a real pain to work with.  Senior IT leadership is unwilling to listen to staff feedback and managers are stuck in the middle.  Lots of 'this is how we have always done it' and very resistant to change.

job_title: Research Assistant in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Professors are very helpful and dedicated to teaching. I learned a lot from my professor and co-workers while working in there. People were very casual and friendly. Free room and board. Access to one of the best gym in Liberal Arts College. Friday picnic.
cons: Compensation was low compared to school from California. But I can't complain since I got paid to work on fun projects and learn science.

job_title: in Saint Paul, MN

cons: Wishy-washy as far as what my job was to be, didn't have regular tasks
